is ongoing.Backed by poundm of investment across - and -, it brings together public sector agencies and the private, education and community sectors.A total of  projects are currently being supported through the initiative.The latest batch includes a pound, bid to boost the centre of Galashiels, capitalising on the future location of the Great Tapestry of Scotland to attract more visitors.Elsewhere, pound, will go towards ReTweed, an award-winning social enterprise based in the fishing town of Eyemouth that teaches women creative skills in craft, design and technology.The cash will allow the scheme to pilot a new business incubator to help women start and grow their own firms.A further pound, will be pumped into ldquogrowing rural skills such as within the dairy and forestry industries.And pound, aims to help increase the number of financially sustainable community enterprise projects in areas such as Stranraer, Upper Nithsdale, Dumfries town centre, Hawick, East Berwickshire, Galashiels and Jedburgh.The pound, announced for Philiphaugh Estate will help it ersy and employ more people, as well as improving visitor attractions and collaborating with local businesses to showcase homegrown produce.Professor Russel Griggs, chairman of SOSEP, hailed the latest funding drive.He said: ldquoThis major funding announcement is fantastic news for the south of Scotland.ldquoFrom wildle to town centre regeneration, these five projects will help support and deliver long-term social and economic benefits to communities in the Scottish Borders and Dumfries and Galloway by creating new businesses, providing vital skills andmaking the region an even more attractive place to visit.ldquoThe economy of the south of Scotland will benefit greatly from this new impetus to stimulate growth and success.A pound.m ldquoBorderlands growth deal was signed in July, aimed at pumping investment into the five local authority areas on both sides of the Border between Scotland and England.Up to poundm is being provided by the UK Government, with poundm coming from the Scottish Government.

title: letters-equal-status-crucial-independence-negotiations
story: There are many ways to achieve that,bearing in mind such factors as the present state assets and liabilities, the national debt, the effect of Westminster policies over the past few decades and so on.The idea that Scotland would have to walk off with, for example, a budget deficit of seven per cent of GDP compared to Englandrsquos one per cent, without there being in place other financial compensating arrangements, some which may be spread over some years, is naiumlve nonsense, and the sooner we stop discussing it in those terms the better.Scotland will be well placed to make sure that a lsquogoodrsquo deal is achieved, and it is time we looked at this matter through that equal status prism.Nick Dekker,Cumbernauld:SNP boss faces sack after independence referendum Plan B blockedWHEN Peter A. Russellclaimed that a letter from European Commission official Viviane Reding defined an independent Scotlandrsquos position in Europe I chose to ignore it. However his subsequent insistence that being on official paper meant it was the definitive legal position of the EU left me with no choice but to intervene and correct him .I now note that despite this he still seems to be maintaining his stance that Ms Redingrsquos letter is still ldquothe best available information on the issue. This appears to be on the basis that Alex Salmondrsquos contrary claim is ldquounsupported by independent legal opinion . I would challenge that latter assertion.Ms Redingrsquos letter is itself unsupported by legal opinion. The situation of a member state splitting in two has not occurred in the history of the EU . So there is no legal precedent.However there is a legal precedent to support Mr Salmondrsquos case for a third country joining the EU without the requirement to go through any negotiations or any revision of the Treaties. When East Germany joined the EU in  it was deemed to be effective from the moment unication with West Germany took place. It was seen to be merely the enlargement of an existing member state with the new combined entity being called lsquoGermanyrsquo.:Neil Mackay: Where have all the big ideas on independence gone An independent Scotland would be in a similar situation, but this time as a third country formed by the reduction in size of an existing member state as opposed to enlargement. Unlike East Germany, however, it would already have met all the criteria for membership by dint of having been in the EU for  years. As such it would be unique and therefore unlike any other third country applying for membership. That is the key point.If the Commission stipulated that Scotland would require to apply for membership like all other third countries, it would have to explain to the European Court of Justice why the legal precedent established by East Germanyrsquos accession to the EU was being disapplied in this instance.By any measure this would be an extremely spurious legal argument for the Commission to advance, especially when Scotland has a stronger economy than East Germany had, was fully compliant with EU rules, and was a known and respected European country with no history of secret police involvement. Methinks the average barrack-room lawyer would simply laugh this one out of court.Robert Menzies,FalkirkTHE picture on page six of The Herald , which accompanies the item about the Peoplersquos Vote rally shows five EU flags being prominently waved. To me, this makes it abundantly clear that the only outcome that this campaign would seek would be to overturn the result of the June  referendum.Christopher W. Ide,Waterfoot, East RenfrewshireTHE SNP are up to their old tricks by barely mentioning independence in the Shetland by-election campaign.In the  general election, Nicola Sturgeon insisted the vote wasnrsquot about separatism, won a landslide - and instantly claimed a mandate for indyref. But the  general election came weeks after the SNP leader had formally demanded indyref - and she promptly lost  seats.Now cue the Shetland by-election campaign, at which the SNP are supposedly focused on opposing Brexit. Remember, Shetland voted Remain. Yet rest assured that,the SNP wins or even grows its vote share, Ms Sturgeon will enthusiastically insist that itrsquos an endorsement of her ambition to separate us from the rest of the UK.Martin Redfern, EdinburghINDEPENDENCE is all very well but sometimes an obsession with it gets in the way of everyday concerns.The Heraldrsquos reportwas depressing to read, The rising cost of living, stagnant wages and cuts in benefits are all contributing to the misery of many Scots. I think more of a focus on alleviating such distress should be at the forefront of our much-lauded SNP Governmentrsquos mind.David Brown, Glasgow

title: blackpool-earthquake
story: The tremor at the Lancashire shale gas site was recorded at about .am on Monday and is stronger than those that forced owners Cuadrilla to suspend test fracking in .It is the fourth quake to hit the area since last Wednesday.How bad were the quakes On Wednesday there was a magnitude . tremor, on Friday night there was one measuring . and on Saturday there was a magnitude . quake and yesterdays was the largest one yet at ., with a depth of . miles.People reported their walls and furniture shaking during the tremors, and hearing a "loud roar" for the duration.Cuadrilla, the oil and gas production company that own the site, said it understood the quake "caused concern for local people" but added: "it is worth noting that this event lasted for around a second and the average ground motion recorded was mm per second".:Issue of the day: Operation YellowhammerWhats causing the quakes Cuadrilla said it was investigating the tremor and no fracking was being carried out at the time.The Oil and Gas Authority have suspended fracking for more than the required  hours while it assesses the seismic activity.What is fracking Fracking, or hydraulic fracturing, is the process of drilling down into the earth before a high-pressure liquid is directed at the rock to release the gas inside - gas which is being considered by governments as a potential energy source.Backers, including Westminster, claim accessing the fossil fuel through fracking could reduce reliance on imports, secure supplies, help cut carbon emissions and create jobs.But opponents say it can cause earthquakes, irreparably damage the countryside and keep the UK hooked on fossil fuels instead of focusing on renewable energy to help tackle climate breakdown.Drilling for shale gas is still at an exploratory phase. However, reserves of shale gas have been identied across large swathes of the UK, particularly in northern England. More than  licences have been awarded by the government, allowing firms to pursue a range of oil and gas exploration activities in certain areas.The Scottish Government has a moratorium in place until further research is completed into frackings environmental impact.Campaigners against the invasive gas-extraction technique are calling on Holyrood to place a full-legislative ban on the process so the more fragile policy ban cant be overturned by future governments.:Issue of the day: Greggs on a vegan rollShould we be worried In , Cuadrilla suspended test fracking operations near Blackpool after earthquakes of . and . magnitude hit the area. It resumed last October after campaigners failed to get an injunction.A subsequent study found it was "highly probable" that shale gas test drilling triggered the tremors.Environmental campaign group Friends of the Earth said in  days of fracking last year there were  tremors in Lancashire and that it cannot be carried out without triggering earthquakes.

title: neil-mackay-big-ideas-independence-gone
story: There are two sides ndash Yes and No ndash but no real debate, and certainly no obvious vision. On the Yes side, nothing has substantively changed, when it comes to big ideas, since the SNP laid out its blueprint for independence in .Brexit has altered the backdrop of the constitutional debate, but apart from a decision by SNP members to support the creation of a new currency as quickly as possible after independence, which many Yes voters donrsquot agree with, therersquos been little in the way of political imagination, creativity and innovation. The plan for Citizensrsquo Assemblies was visionary but itrsquos been undermined by SNP politicisation.Thatrsquos not to say that hard work hasnrsquot been done on the nuts and bolts of independence. The SNPrsquos Growth Commission report on the finances of an independent Scotland presented some serious economic thinking, but this is not the stuff upon which visions of new nations are built, this is the stuff of the seminar room.: Neil Mackay:Irsquom a Yes voter, but Irsquom now sick and tired of my own sideThe No side is even worse. All thatrsquos heard from the No camp is the word lsquoNorsquo. Wherersquos their vision of what a Scotland remaining in the union will look like  Brexit has shown both the Tories and Labour to be intellectually bankrupt when it comes to the future of Scotland. Yoursquod get more vision walking around a darkened room with your eyes closed than you would listening to most unionist politicians in Scotland.The new co-leader of the Scottish Green Party, Lorna Slater, seems to share concerns about the level of intellectual debate around the future of Scotland. She too worries about the vision thing.Slater has identied a few problems. Firstly, the impression that the SNP ldquoowns the idea of independence. Many Yes voters donrsquot support the SNP ndash yet itrsquos the SNP which dictates most of the discussion around independence. When a monolithic, managerial party controls debate then the drain on vision wersquore experiencing is inevitable. Whatrsquos good for the SNP in terms of holding on to power isnrsquot necessarily in the best interests of independence.A resurgence of all those grassroots Yes organisations which sprung up as the first referendum approached would provide an intellectual counterweight to the SNP, and a laboratory for new ideas.Slater is also concerned that ldquomuch of the debate around independence has focused on whether or not there should be a referendum. We should be focusing on what we want an independent Scotland to look like.Shersquos right. A second referendum will happen at some stage in the relatively near future, but what really matters,you are a Yes voter, is making sure the vision for the country is in place in order to convince the people that independence is the right course of action when the time comes.Brexit has taught us hard lessons. There was no real discussion, no real vision, about what a post-Brexit Britain would look like. A national conversation needs to begin in Scotland about the kind of country we want to be after independence.What about a constitution  The monarchy  The nature of the army  Our relationship with America  A second parliamentary chamber  Our role in Europe These issues cannot be left up to the SNP. Politicians make decisions in the best interests of their party, not the country. Parties care about power not people.We need to know the substance of what wersquore voting for, rather than the intellectually bereft binary of Yes and No. The Greens are certainly setting out a clear vision for Scotland after independence. The environment will be the top priority, there will be a move away from oil and gas.Of course, the Greens also flatlined on around eight per cent of the vote during the European elections in May. However, that disappointment may account for their renewed push for a big vision for Scotland now.The Greens need to get out from under the shadow of the SNP. Being seen by voters as "the other party which also supports independence" isnrsquot a strategy, especially when Greens can provide a clear, progressive vision for the country which the SNP with its disparate factions cannot.The SNP is ready to splinter into left, right and centre the moment Scotland becomes independent. In the era of climate change, the Greens have a simple and important story to tell which other parties do not.However, honesty is the greatest storyline ndash the strongest vision ndash to present to Scotland. So letrsquos be honest. If Scotland votes Yes to independence in any future referendum, we need to accept that it is inevitable that the nation will need a confirmatory referendum on any deal negotiated with the rest of the UK regarding separation.Dr Alan Renwick, of University College Londonrsquos Constitution Unit, has raised this issue saying that a confirmatory vote would avoid the ldquoacrimony and gridlock of Brexit. He refers to the ldquograve democratic quandary where the public has not been allowed to make ldquoan informed choice about the type of Brexit the country goes through. Renwick suggests opting for a confirmatory vote might increase the turnout for Yes with the public willing to back independence in theory and then see what the politicians negotiate.A future independence referendum would be a ldquopre-legislative ballot, instructing politicians to negotiate a deal which we then vote on. That seems perfectly democratic and the kind of vision we need for this country.:Majority now want Scottish independence, says phenomenal new pollIt immediately shows a commitment to democracy over party politics, a willingness to tackle emotional and isive subjects in a collegiate way, and it projects an adult image of this nation while many other countries seem to be reverting to childhood.The First Minister Nicola Sturgeon and some of her inner circle may be publicly voicing their discomfort with the baggage that comes with the concept of nationalism of late, in an attempt to woo soft No voters, but the one thing which will change swithering minds is honestly tackling the dficulties which the journey towards independence will involve.It will not be easy - it will be hard. Admitting those dficulties is a good way to start presenting a vision of integrity and honour for a new independent Scotland.Neil Mackay is Scotlandrsquos Columnist of the Year

title: oscar-marzaroli-man-captured-forgotten-moments-glasgow-life
story: The photograph is typical Oscar Marzaroli. Taken in , it preserves a moment asin aspic, an anonymous sliver of Glasgow le.But it wasnrsquot part of a y photo shoot. The celebrated photographer was in the city centre to photograph a student rag parade, which at the time was a busy, raucous event. It is alleged that it even featured an elephant.:Le through a lens: the unseen treasures of Oscar MarzaroliYet Marzaroli broke off to capture the quietly transfixed moment for this one shot, the only one of the child in the set of parade negatives.The same photographerrsquos famous image Castlemilk Lads  Again, he took only one.That is one of the reasons why a donation of Marzarolirsquos entire collection of negatives ndash on the th anniversary of his death ndash so excites the archivists at Glasgow Caledonian University . Nobody quite knows what it contains.He has become identied with ndash almost synonymous with ndash photographs of Glasgow in the s, not least after Deacon Blue used several of his images for single and album covers in the s. But Marzaroli worked primarily as a film-maker, making dozens of documentaries for the Highlands and Islands Development Board.His camera was ever present, however, and his photographs are now regarded by many as art.At an event at the university last night, Deacon Blue lead singer Ricky Ross launched a campaign to raise pound, to enable the entire collection to be made freely available online.The money is needed to carry out the work necessary to preserve, catalogue and digitise the images into a searchable online collection.Glasgow subway The image of the child at the bookshop window is one of  original prints, all but one developed by Marzaroli himself, to be auctioned to kick-start the fund in an event which runs until Thursday, September .Italian born, Oscar Marzaroli moved to Scotland at the age of two. He missed out on much formal education and did not go to art school as his brother had, largely as a result of childhood ill-health.He spent a year in Kingussie Sanatorium fighting TB in his late teens ndash there was doubt as to whether he would recover. Soon afterwards he was in a motorcycle accident.:Pictures of the dayldquoHe felt his whole le that he was living on borrowed time, says Marie-Claire Marzaroli, one of his three daughters. ldquoI think it gave him a kind of focus. She argues an egalitarian outlook also contributed to his ability to capture a sense of someonersquos personality.:THOSE WERE THE DAYSS: Oscar Marzaroli, Glasgows patrician with a cameraldquoHe didnrsquot like hierarchies. He would spend the same amount of time with someone, whether he was photographing a big film star or someone selling him fish.Through portraits and landscapes, he captured Scotland and its people at a time of great social change in the s, s and s. Many of his photographs of Glasgowprovide a record of signicant social change, as city slums were being cleared to make way for new social housing.The huge body of work is perhaps surprising given his untimely death on August , , at the age of .During a three-decade search for a permanent home for their fatherrsquos work, Marie-Claire and her sister Nicola say it wasnrsquot until meeting archivist Carole McCallum at GCU that they felt confident they had found a solution that satisfied them and which would have pleased him.Both teachers, they are thrilled at plans to digitise the collection and make it freely available online. ldquoIt was our motherrsquos wish we find the right setting to preserve his legacy and the family are excited by the universityrsquos plans, Marie-Claire says.There is excitement too about what might be found when the negatives are fully catalogued. While there are contact sheets in some of Marzarolirsquos files, only around , of the images have ever been printed up, and there is no certainty about what is contained in many of the negatives.Some spools of film, retrieved from his camera bag, have never even been developed. Nicola says: ldquoThere are so many images, even we do not know what treasures our dad has left hidden in thereLaunching the appeal, singer-songwriter Ross said: ldquoI got in touch with Oscar after I became fascinated with his work, and he ended up coming out with us and shooting some photographs for our first Deacon Blue album in dferent locations.ldquoIrsquod told him about the idea of Raintown and he called me one day to say there was a picture he thought suited it.St Enoch SquareldquoItrsquos the one of the sunshine coming through the clouds. We loved it and our music from that period has been linked to Oscar ever since, he said.University archivist Carole McCallum says the Marzaroli Collection is of international importance. ldquoOscarrsquos photographs are instantly recognisable ndash particularly the iconic images he took in the Gorbals before the tenements were cleared away.Theyrsquove become rooted in popular culture, but people donrsquot realise Oscar worked all over Scotland and further afield both as a photographer and filmmaker. We are tremendously excited about putting the archive online.

title: harvey-weinstein-trial-postponed-2020-light-fresh-evidence
story: The change to the case was intended to open the door for an actress to give evidence against Weinstein in a rape and sexual assault trial that had been scheduled to start on September .:Harvey Weinstein due in New York court in sex assault caseWeinstein mostly kept quiet during a brief appearance in a Manhattan courtroom aside from some brief exchanges with Judge James Burke, who at one point scolded him for pulling out his mobile phone during the proceeding.After the judge agreed with defence lawyers that the trial needed to be put off so they could have time to respond to the revised charges, he told them the new trial date of January  was firm.To make the point, he stared at the defendant and asked, ldquoMr Weinstein, do you want to go to trial ldquoNot really, Weinstein quipped.Weinstein, , who is free on one million US dollars bail, has denied all accusations of non-consensual sex.After the hearing, his lawyers said they would ask the judge to dismiss the indictment, which they called a ldquodesperate attempt to salvage the case.ldquoI think the case itself is weak, said his lawyer Donna Rotunno.Weinstein previously pleaded not guilty to charges accusing him of raping a woman in  and performing a forcible sex act on a dferent woman in .The case remains about those two women, but prosecutors said the new indictment was needed to allow a third woman, Annabella Sciorra, to give evidence.Sciorra, who is best known for her work on The Sopranos, says Weinstein raped her inside her Manhattan apartment after she starred in a film for his movie studio in .:New BBC documentary explores Harvey Weinstein allegationsProsecutors cannot charge Weinstein with the alleged attack on Sciorra because it took place too long ago to be prosecuted under state law, but they want to use her evidence to prove that Weinstein had a pattern of assaulting women.That is necessary to prove the charge of predatory sexual assault.Sciorrarsquos lawyer, Gloria Allred, said she was willing to tell her story to bring Weinstein to justice.She criticised the defence team for saying they would try to get her evidence barred.ldquoWhy are they so afraid of having additional witnesses testy  she said.Sciorra went public with her story in a story in The New Yorker in October .Court papers filed by the defence called the attempt to make Sciorra a prosecution witness an ldquoth-hour manoeuvre that ldquoraises signicant legal issues and had predicted it could delay the trial.Separately, defence lawyers have asked an appeals court to move the trial case out title: farmers-hold-key-make-country-greener
story: Farming is hugely important in this debate as over % of land in the UK is farmed in some way or other.The report will have increased the publicrsquos awareness of the interdependence between agriculture and the environment, but not in a manner which will make farmers sleep more easily at night.The challenges set out in the IPCC report come on top of uncertainties in the level and nature of future farm subsidies, and uncertainties in the future for food trade as a result of us leaving the EU.Together they mean that the UK farm sector is facing an existential crisis, which all but The Archers seem to be aware of. Behind the headlines, the IPCC report includes a much more positive message about the potential agriculture has for helping to mitigate climate change.:Fe farmer bids to put buffalo mozzarella on the menuUnlike other sectors, agriculture can, through appropriate changes in land use and new land management practices, not only reduce its greenhouse gas emissions but sequester more carbon, offsetting emissions in other sectors.The same changes in land use and land management will also help stem the decline in bioersity and our natural resources, or what the economist Dieter Helm and others refer to as our ldquonatural capital.In his latest book ldquoGreen and Prosperous Land, Helm argues that protecting and enhancing our environment is one of the best investments that a society can make and that agriculture, with the support of appropriate policies, has a key role in moving us towards a sustainable future.The signs are that, post-Brexit, UK agricultural policy will place more, rather than less, emphasis on the environmental objectives of farming.It follows that farmers should welcome the increased attention being given to the environment.In reality, agri-environmental policies explicitly focused on ensuring farming delivers environmental public goods are not new. However, despite the clear and long-standing policy support for protecting the farmed environment, and notwithstanding recent commitments by farm lobby groups to achieving net-zero production, many farmers see their primary, and in some cases sole, role being that of producingfood.Why is this  In part it could be attributed to the nature of some past agri-environmental schemes.Many have been bureaucratically demanding while others have, inadvertently, included conditions which placed future farm support payments at risk.While some measures have clear environmental gains and are relatively easy for farmers to adopt, eg restoring peat bogs on land, not in productive use, often the schemes are necessarily more complex.:Five Scottish farm-themed wedding venuesNatural habitats need to be connected toeffectively, often across farm boundaries, therefore requiring new levels of co-operation between neighbouring farmers the right sort of trees need to be planted in the right types of land for net positive carbon sequestration to occur, and the time period within which the trees will generate income may not align with a farmerrsquos needs. However, new farming technologies and methods are emerging that will hopefully breakdown this  dichotomy between food production and environmental protection.Another example is agroforestry which provides productivity and welfare benefits to livestock as well as the carbon sequestration benefits from trees.The uptake of these and other agri-ecological approaches is being demonstrated by innovators in the sector and will be supported by UK policies, which recognise the importance of farm-based natural capital.Moreover, disruptive technologies are fast emerging which will provide yet more opportunities for the sector to show its environmental credentials.For example, indoor vertical farming offers huge environmental benefits in terms of reducing food waste, eliminating the need for agro-chemicals in crop production, reducing water requirements, and, by producing food where it is needed, reducing food miles and sparing land. A recent Scottish Government study found that  per cent of the public rated the environment as one of the top three government portfolios that should be prioritised in terms of spending.Agriculture came much further down the list, with just % of the public rating it. In particular, over half of the participants in the forumwanted to see a greater share of agricultural support funding going to support the natural environment. The publicrsquos views were changed. The question is therefore whether farmers will embrace the opportunity Deborah Roberts is director of science at The James Hutton Institute.

title: green-msp-retire-next-holyrood-election
story: Highlands and Islands MSP John Finnie has announced he will step down at the next election after a decade in the parliament.It comes as his party, which currently has six MSPs, starts selecting candidates for .Mr Finnie, , is behind the proposed ban on smacking, which began as a private memberrsquos bill that went on to receive Scottish Government support.In the wake of this yearrsquos budget deal between the SNP and Greens, Mr Finnie has also been spearheading the proposed workplace parking levy, or parking tax.The former police officer was the first Green elected in the Highlands and Islands, winning on the list system in  and again in .He is one half of the only father and child double act at parliament - his daughter Ruth Maguire is the SNP MSP for Cunninghame South.He said: ldquoIt is an honour to serve the Highlands and Islands in the Scottish Parliament and I intend continuing to work hard until my last day in office.ldquoIrsquove been involved in representative politics since being elected a Highland Councillor in  and enjoyed helping people, but I feel the time is right to step aside and let others bring their energy and ideas to what is a demanding job.ldquoThroughout my time in Parliament, Irsquove put my home region of the Highlands and Islands and my constituents at the forefront of my work. Driven by my interest in social and environmental justice, I have been pleased to secure a number of concessions and legislative changes to improve the lives of people in the region.ldquoAt this time, Irsquom focused on working with others to secure the passage of my Memberrsquos Bill giving children equal protection from assault and hope to see it become law in the near future.ldquoThe Climate Emergency our planet is facing means that, more than ever, Green policies are required. I know there are others who can ensure they are promoted, and delivered, for my home, the Highlands and Islands of Scotland. Meanwhile, I look forward to having more time to spend with my family.

title: sturgeon-criticised-visiting-shetland-39-s-election
story: With voters going to the polls on Thursday in a two-horse race between the LibDems and SNP, Ms Sturgeon has been in the seat three times since July .However it has emerged she has only been in title: dons from the don telling it like it is
story: Stand By Your Man!By the time you read this week’s DFTD, Aberdeen’s board may have panicked and relieved our manager of his duties.This would be a ridiculously short-sighted move, perhaps temporarily appeasing the sixth-form style thinkers in their creepy chatrooms or the small deluded bunch still loyal to the big loon who enjoys a pint doon the Govan Bowling Club.Indeed the stadium was awash with stories of histo the fold, Heaven forbid. The nine-nil reverse at Celtic Park was undeniably sore and damaging to the football club.However, it was fty-nine minutes of complete and utter madness that saw Celtic convert every one of their attempts on target bar two.It followed a decent half hour for the Dons that included a great chance for Chris Maguire.The game was of the freakish type that beset a far better Dons side at MacDiarmid Park under Alex Smith for example.Paul Hartley knows that he let his new club down but to criticize our skipper would be churlish in the extreme, given what he has already contributed to the cause.It was a miserable afternoon that will have been incredibly welcome for Doogie McDonald, the debacle temporarily removing the untruthful official from the media glare.The heavy loss understandably made Tuesday night’s Inverness clash take on extra importance but Aberdeen’s luck was totally out.If anyone thinks any of the Dons players didn’t give % against ICT they don’t know football.Watching the game upon getting home from the match you actually started believing that the Dons had to win, given the total dominance in the second half.Inverness took the lead due to simulation of the most repulsive type.The poor referee had a night to forget from beginning to end and the last thing he needed was players feigning and faking.The farcical penalty only served to double the Dons’ resolve.First half additional time was measured at two minutes which means that no injury time was played once factoring in the four yellows that had been flashed in the first period.The second half saw the passing and movement back to what we were enjoying back in August and the goal from Velicka was a belter, sent on his way by the best player of the field by a country mile – Scottie Vernon.The ref was given the chance to correct his penalty howler by awarding one to the home team but one assumes he must have been unsighted for the blatant hand-ball.The Inverness winner came from a free-kick that never was at the half way line, poor defending but rough, rough justice on a Dons team that gave everything.There was still time for Foran to try and get Ifil sent off and the game’s close saw the classless Butcher provocatively gesticulating in front of the RDS, doubly stupid given the pressure on a fellow boss. Mark McGhee was bullish and quite excellent in his post-match interviews on Tuesday.I do hope that the board hold their nerve and properly take into account the budget they have forced their employee to work with and by definition the worryingly youthful squad that has resulted.Standing good for a manageable debt is fine and dandy but more and more fans are scratching their heads and querying why fantastically rich iniduals are involvedthey have no intention of investing in the area’s only senior football club.Someone called the new ground ‘a vanity stadium’ this week and that is a brilliant description.Great rationale, lousy location.It’s taken the focus off the football.Mark McGhee will undoubtedly question his own decisions and soul search to get things right at a football club he loves but the great and good need to do likewise.The Dons are on the cusp of a very exciting team in the next couple of seasons but onlyeveryone in the Dons family sticks together.Celtic’s Anti-Poppy ShameGlasgow Celtic were said to be embarrassed and angered by sections of their support unfurling ious disgraceful banners on Saturday.The club, who has had issues at this time of the year before, ironically has since enjoyed warm plaudits for the swtness of their ‘condemnation’.Talk of bans has ensued, but you will forgive mewe file this under ‘Old Firm Lip Service’.British Heavyweights No boxing fan would ever claim to have Harrison or Haye anywhere near the all-time British greats type description, but I can’t help but be sucked into the intrigue as the two Brits go toe-to-toe on Saturday night.Many a sneaky tenner will be placed on Harrison to spring a surprise.Haye will need to take care of business as soon as possible as even Lennox Lewis was twice undone by random rogue punches – something always on the radar in this ision. title: aberdeenshire part of a new national network to save our sound heritage
story: Unique and rare recordings of Scottish traditional music made in Aberdeenshire in the s through to the s are to be preserved as part of a national initiative led by the British Library.Unlocking Our Sound Heritage is a major £. million sound preservation and access project, which has received a £. million National Lottery Heritage Fund grant.It has seen the formation of the first ever network of ten sound preservation centres, including one at the National Library of Scotland.This UK-wide partnership of institutions aims to digitally preserve half a million of the nation’s most rare and at-risk sounds and share them as widely as possible.Reel-to-reel tape recordings from the John Junner Collection - recently donated to Live Le Aberdeenshire’s Museum Service - were selected as one of the Scottish beneficiaries.The full collection comprises musical instruments, recording and playing equipment, and music recordings on wax cylinders, tapes and cassettes.Junnerwas a schoolteacher and esteemed musician from Strachan, Aberdeenshire.An acknowledged authority on the music of James Scott Skinner – Banchory’s famous dancing master, violinist, fiddler and composer – he was interested in sound, its mechanical production and reproduction on ious machines.Over the years he recorded many local musicians. His musical collecting and recordings pre-dates the Folk Revival of the s and s and consequently are unique.David Cook, sub-committee chair of Live Le Aberdeenshire, said: “We are delighted to accept this unique collection of local and national signicance into the permanentcollections of Aberdeenshire Council Museums.“Whilst the recordings are in good condition, they are threatened by physical degradation and some are stored on formats that can no longer be played. Being part of this national initiative will ensure some of our local recordings of Scots music will be digitally preserved and available to folk at home and abroad for future enjoyment and learning.”Alastair Hardie, one of the trustees acting on behalf of the late John Junner, said: “In his will, John Junner asked for his collection to be kept ‘at a suitable location in northeast Scotland’.data-src"https:images-o.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"Aberdeenshire Provost Bill Howatson said armed forces personnel make huge sacrices to keep us all safe"  Aberdeenshire Council achieves gold award for work with armed forces, families, veterans and cadetsviewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z" data-src"https:images-o.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"It is claimed the Violet Route for dualling the A could endanger Fyfe House"  Action group “appalled” at threat to Guiding house viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "INVE | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "INVE | Article Teaser""Ten years after his death, his wish has finally been fulfilled with this donation. Having the collection in the care of Aberdeenshire Council Museum Service will help to ensure the long-term wellbeing, development and accessibility of the John Junner Collection for posterity.”The major grant from the National Lottery Heritage Fund is allowing the network to develop a range of engagement activities to connect the wider public with their sound heritage. A key element of Unlocking Our Sound Heritage will be an interactive website hosted by the British Library, launching in , allowing listeners to explore a wide selection of recordings.Dr John Scally, Scotland’s National Librarian, said: “Our sound heritage is under threat as tapes, minidiscs and lacquer, vinyl and shellac discs degrade or equipment to play them becomes obsolete.“This is a vitally important project that will help to save the nation’s sounds and preserve them to be enjoyed for many generations to come.”

title: garioch sports centre serves up an ace with new tennis plans
story: With the nation currently hooked on Wimbledon, it#s a fitting time for Garioch Sports Centre to unveil its new tennis-focused proposals.Inverurie Community Council has submitted fresh expansion plans to Aberdeenshire Council on behalf of Garioch Sports Holdings.Full planning permission was secured last year for a major extension of the Inverurie facility, but changes in the community’s requirements and pressures on funding have prompted a reduced development.Initially the plans would have seen the Burghmuir Drive centre expanding into one of the largest amenities of its kind in Scotland, incorporating tennis courts, a multi-sports arena, fitness suites and an all-weather G pitch for Inverurie Loco Works FC which has now been dropped.But while the scale of the expansion might not be as ambitious, the new plans do reveal tennis courts and improvements for fitness along with an Early Learning Centre for younger children.Thanks to signicant input from Judy Murray – mother of to develop the sport across Garioch.The centre and JM Foundation will work in partnership in upskilling their workforce and identying potential coaches while funding coach education.In a supporting statement the centre writes: “The matter of securing the appropriate funding for the ious options which have been considered over the last couple of years has impacted upon how the plans have altered Murray has also been pivotal in how the plans particularly for the tennis courts have progressed.”The applicants also believe that despite the downturn in oil and gas and other industries, there is The additional roles are part of package of improvements agreed by councillors in January.However, a new permit scheme is also being introduced to move business waste away from recycling centres to create more space for new recyclable materials to improve services to householders.While most businesses pay the necessary fees to dispose of their waste and recycling responsibly, the current open access to recycling centres means some business waste is being presented as household waste so that it can be processed free of charge.To tackle this, a new permit scheme is one of the measures being introduced next year to prevent such abuse. Under the new scheme householders using commercial type vehicles - vans, pick-ups, minibuses or trailers - to take materials to recycling centres will require a permit to do so.The permits will be title: final flight for flying banker
story: A Royal Bank of Scotland employee who has flown almost , trips in Orkney is celebrating retirement after  years as the UK’s only full-time ‘flying banker’.Clocking up more than , journeys on Loganair’s eight-seat Britten Norman Islander, which provides the Orkney Inter-Isle air service, Anne helped Royal Bank of Scotland customers in the isles branches.Anne served around  to  customers during each visit, from crofters to fishermen to those in the tourist industries.She is only the second person to have held this exclusive role, taking over from Maisie Muir who started the flying service in . Prior to that a banking boat, known as the Otter Bank and skippered by Anne’s great uncle, docked at each of the islands served by the bank.Officially recognised for her service, Anne was awarded an MBE in  and has worked for the bank for  years, serving customers at the branch in Kirkwall before she took on the flying banker role.Her recent farewell flight was the -minute journey from Westray to Kirkwall, piloted by long-serving Captain Colin McAllister. The aircraft was met with a water cannon salute by the airport’s fire brigade and Anne was presented with retirement gts and a Loganair membership card entitling her to two freetickets and unlimited ticket upgrades whenever she travels.As Anne left the final flight of her career she was met by Liam McArthur MSP, Bill Spence, Lord-Lieutenant of Orkney, her Kirkwall branch colleagues, Loganair and airport employees – who gave Anne a guard of honour as she walked to the terminal.Another resident of Orkney, Lois Canning, who joined Royal Bank of Scotland in  has been appointed to the role. Lois lives on the island of Shapinsay and takes the ferry to work every day. She is currently a personal banker in the Kirkwall branch.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: highlands and islands msp to retire at next election
story: Highlands and Islands Green MSP John Finnie has announced that he will retire at the next Scottish Parliamentary election.The Scottish Greens have begun selecting candidates for the election in  and Mr Finnie, who was first elected to represent the Highlands and Islands in  and subsequently re-elected in , has indicated that he will not seek a further term.Speaking of his decision, which he announced earlier today, Mr Finnie said: “It is an honour to serve the Highlands and Islands in the Scottish Parliament and I intend continuing to work hard until my last day in office.“I’ve been involved in representative politics since being elected a Highland Councillor in  and enjoyed helping people, but I feel the time is right to step aside and let others bring their energy and ideas to what is a demanding job.“Throughout my time in Parliament, I’ve put my home region of the Highlands and Islands and my constituents at the forefront of my work. Driven by my interest in social and environmental justice, I have been pleased to secure a number of concessions and legislative changes to improve the lives of people in the region.“At this time, I’m focused on working with others to secure the passage of my Member’s Bill giving children equal protection from assault and hope to see it become law in the near future.“The Climate Emergency our planet is facing means that, more than ever, Green policies are required. I know there are others who can ensure they are promoted, and delivered, for my home, the Highlands and Islands of Scotland. Meanwhile, I look forward to having more time to spend with my family.”Mr Finnie is one of four list MSPs who currently write monthly columns for The Orcadian.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: next phase of kirkwall thi announced
story: The second phase of works under the Kirkwall Townscape Heritage Initiativeand the Places and Spaces project is due to get underway at the beginning of next month.Orkney Islands Council is reporting that the works include new paving outside the Orkney Museum, a new parking area outside the former Spence’s newsagent and new paving into Victoria Street.This will take place from September until February, with work suspended through the whole of December to support shopping on the street during the festive period. Free parking of up to one hour will apply as usual in metered car parks over the winter period.Tankerness Lane will be closed to vehicles throughout the works, with one-way systems in place at ious times on Broad Street and Palace Road — with Victoria Street closed to vehicles for approximately five weeks from  January . Pedestrian access will be maintained throughout.The council has said the key aspects of the Place and Spaces project are to improve the area at the bottom of the Strynd and top of Castle Street, provide a new path to the war memorial to enhance it as a place to stop and reflect on the signicance of the monument and improve the head of Victoria Street to encourage more people into this part of the town.Depute council leader, councillor Leslie Manson, said: “The works carried out in Kirkwall’s town centre through our Townscape Heritage Initiative Scheme have given our streets and buildings a much-needed new lease of le, whether that be improvements to the shop fronts or the attractive new paving at the head of Broad Street.“This latest phase is aimed at improving the entrance to Victoria Street to encourage more shoppers and visitors to take a wander down this street — a long-held aspiration of the businesses that are situated there.“There will, of course, be some inevitable disruption, but we’ve worked hard to ensure that this is kept to a minimum, including suspending works for the Christmas period. I look forward to seeing the improvements that are made and the effect these have on our historic streets.”copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: oic to appoint new head of education leisure and housing
story: Orkney Islands Council has announced who will take up the role of executive director of education, leisure and housing, when the current executive director, Wilfred Weir, retires later this year.James Wylie will be taking up the post from Mr Weir, who announced his intention to retire this coming Autumn, after five years in post.Mr Wylie is currently the council#s Head of Education .OIC convener, councillor Harvey Johnston, said: “We interviewed a strong field of candidates and I would like to offer my congratulations to James, who has accepted this opportunity to take on a role of great importance to the council and to the wider community we serve.”Councillor Gwenda Shearer, chairwoman of the education, leisure and housing committee, said: “The post provides the chance to make a positive and lasting impact on the lives of children, young people and adult learners, on the tenants of the housing we provide and on the many people who use our leisure facilities — from museums and libraries to swimming pools and healthy living centres.“I would like to thank all the candidates we interviewed and wish James all the best in this rewarding and challenging new role.”copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: work set to begin at scapa flow museum
story: Work to restore and improve the Scapa Flow Museum is set to begin next month, Orkney Islands Council has said.This follows a recent decision by the local authority to take forward a revised project at Lyness.The council has said the aim is to concentrate efforts on renovating the historic pump house and on building an extension to the museum, with an Orkney-based company recently appointed to carry out the work. A refurbished and extended museum is expected to re-open during the summer of .Council leader James Stockan said: “This is a project of tremendous signicance for Hoy and for Orkney as a whole.“It has taken longer than we first hoped to get to this stage and it will be excellent for all involved to see work getting underway soon.“I am delighted that, like the council, the project’s external funders remain fully committed to the scheme.“When complete, the restored and extended museum will for the first time in many years open all year round, encouraging more people to visit Hoy and boosting tourism throughout the island.”The museum’s role is to chart Orkney’s military involvement in the First and Second World Wars and provide a safe home for a major collection of wartime artefacts, many of national and international importance.After a competitive tendering exercise, the contract for the work has been awarded to Orkney BuildersLtd.A temporary exhibition on the wartime history of Scapa Flow is on show at the Hoy Hotel while the museum is closed. This has been part-funded through the Island of Hoy Development Trust.Repairs to the Romney Hut at Lyness and options for the Oil Tank will be considered at a later date.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co.
