title: Adventurous couple build tiny home
story: WHEN it comes to their first home together, local couple Michael Rauch and Alex Connolly are thinking small mdash not big.The  year-olds are embracing the global home phenomenon of living in a tiny house on wheels.Michael and Alex are transforming a former flatbed trailer into a one-bedroom home in Lisbane that will lend itself to the simple, non-materialistic lestyle that they favour.With the average home in Co Down now in the region of pound,, the young couple will get their first home at a fraction of the cost.ldquoI reckon that once everything is finished, our tiny home will cost up between pound, to pound,, said Michael.ldquoWe paid around pound, for the second-hand trailer and it was quite dficult to get one big enough and wide enough. Then I got a local engineer to sandblast it and paint it so that is was like new and that cost another few thousand.ldquoThe rest of the cost will be spent on the build and the fit out inside. I reckon that even after we live in it for a while, it would still retain some valuewe wanted to sell itwe decide to travel again or rent it out. I see the cost as the equivalent to three yearsrsquo rent and itrsquos money not wasted as we still have something at the end of it.The tiny home concept mdashnormally one bed studio-style homes mdash has become popular for people looking for a simpler way of living in locations that they can change and without tying themselves down to massive mortgage.Michael, who is from Whiterock, and Alex, who is from Saintfield, discovered the concept while travelling and living in a small van in New Zealand for a year.ldquoI had been aware of tiny houses before we went to New Zealand and over there it is really popular, explained Michael. ldquoThey really are everywhere. Seeing how people live in these tiny houses inspired me that it could be done here too.ldquoWe lived in one of them during our time in New Zealand and loved it. It did simply our lives and it was a bit more sustainable which is a big thing is for us.ldquoWe donrsquot like the idea of renting for the next few years or being tied down to a mortgage and this allows us to be flexible, plus it is a bit adventurous.The couple, who first began to date after getting together at their leaving formal at Down High School, have designed their home with a galley kitchen with sitting area, a small shower room and loft bedroom in a building that is six metres long by . metres wide and . metres high.The house should be finished in time for Christmas and is kept near Lisbane where the couple try to work on it every day.Michael, a design engineer graduate, and Alex, who graduated in textile and design, are both working part-time jobs at the moment in order to devote themselves to the build.Michael said: ldquoWersquove done all the work ourselves in order to save money and to gain more skills. The exterior is nearly finished so we will be moving on to the interior soon.ldquoRegarding installing the utilities, some have pretty easy solutions and some are more dficult. As we would like some flexibility as to where we can park it, we donrsquot want to plug into mains electricity or the sewerage system, so the shower will be a standard shower with an instant water heater. Any grey water from the sink or shower will be probably be handled by some kind of natural filtration.Michael and Alex donrsquot yet know where they will site their home when it is finished but hope to place it on land owned by friends, or to rent out a field.They say that part of the reason to build their tiny home is financial, but also down to the way of le that living in such a small space brings with it.Michael said: ldquoWe like to do something more meaningful with our money and prefer travel experiences. We would rather not spend loads of money on a sofa mdash we would prefer to go travelling.He added: ldquoI would love to convert a camper van and go around Europe. I really donrsquot see the sense of buying up stuff and would rather have experiences that I would remember more.The couple want to have a cosy feeling to their home but not something too modern.Like caravans or boats, space is at a premium in a tiny house and Michael has designed stairs up to their loft bed so that extra storage can be built in.ldquoWe donrsquot have that much stuff which is good. Often when people do move into these small houses they find it dficult to get rid of a lot of stuff, he added..prettyPhoto

title: Call for play park upgrade
story: MOTHERS in Ballynahinch are demanding that immediate improvements are made to the play park in Hillfoot Crescent.The women claim that due to vandalism and a lack of maintenance, the play facility is in dire need of an upgrade and is not fit for purpose to serve the needs of local children.The members of Hillfoot Crescent and Windmill Residents Association also say that the play facility is long overdue for some general weed tidying up by Newry, Mourne and Down Council which is responsible for it.A large group of women and children held an open meeting at the park last Thursday and invited local councillors to attend to see at first hand the poor state the park has declined into.Rowallane councillor Terry Andrews told the mothers, grandmothers and children that Hillfoot Crescent was one of three local parks due to be upgraded by the council within the next two years.However, while Ursula Jess, secretary of Hillfoot Crescent and Windmill Residents Association, welcomed the news, she said that the association would still be pressing for some interim improvements.ldquoItrsquos good to hear that a new play facility upgrade is supposed to be in the pipeline but we need something done between now and then, she said.ldquoWe urgently need it upgraded as therersquos no summer seats and parents and minders either have to stand or sit on the grass to keep an eye on the children and itrsquos not good enough. The seats were burnt one by one years ago and never replaced sowe were to get summer seats between now and the upgrade, it would be helpful.Mrs Jess said that Hillfoot Crescent got a Lottery grant in the late s to install the park and over the years broken equipment has not been replaced.She added: ldquoItrsquos a massive park with a lot of potential. We still have some tyre swings, a climbing frame, a slide and baby swings. There used to be a basket ball hoop but that is away now.ldquoItrsquos all been down to vandalism and general wear and tear. When the little elephant rockers were broken, the council just came and took them away but they werenrsquot replaced.She said that the play arearsquos summer seats were only replaced on one occasion after local vandals burnt them and had have not been replaced for years.Mrs Jess said that the community has done its best to keep the play park safe by sweeping away any broken glass and rubbish and have raised money for equipment in the past.The play facility caters for a large numbers of families at Millbank Grove Windmill Gardens, Windmill Drive, Windmill View, Carlisle Park and further afield, added Mrs Jess.Cllr Andrews said that he welcomed the residentsrsquo invitation to come along and to find out about the play facility.He said: ldquoThe play facility at Hillfoot Crescent serves a big catchment area with new developments being built in recent years.ldquoI was very impressed by the excellent turnout of parents, neighbours and children to convey their frustrations, worries and concerns about the condition of the existing playground here and the sense of being forgotten about.ldquoThey are calling for an upgrade to state of the art play parks that others in the Rowallane District Electoral Areahave been supplied with in recent times.ldquoI was able to tell them that Hillfoot Crescent is included in the line-up for an upgrade to new state of the art equipment.ldquoI will be lobbying and supporting this call at council level for this much-needed new play park to go ahead speedily along with those for Darragh Cross and Kilmore.The councillor said the council will encourage local residents and children to have their say and input into the new playground.He was presented with a heart-felt plea from the children for their park to be improved which was written as a poem and presented to him.It read: ldquoOur park is dying, itrsquos so sad, No one cares that it looks so bad.A lick of paint a bench or two, A modern slide area all overdue, So come on Council what do you say  Help us out and let us play..prettyPhoto

title: Call to clean up Mary Street area of Crossgar
story: CALLS have been issued for a clean-up of the Mary Street area in Crossgar.South Down MLA Colin McGrath and Rowallane councillor Terry Andrews have highlighted the need for the work to be carried out following a recent visit to the village.Mr McGrath mdash who was in Crossgar along with Cllr Andrews to listen to residentsrsquo concerns mdash is keen to see a resolution to the issues in Mary Street.ldquoPaths at this part of the village have become very poorly neglected and a dumping ground for some, the MLA explained.ldquoThis is totally unacceptable at a location adjacent to residentsrsquo garages and homes and the issue needs to be addressed as soon as possible.Mr McGrath suggested that the Mary Street problems are indicative of a wider issue people and groups across the country are going to have to get to grips with mdash determining who is responsible for certain pockets of land.He continued: ldquoBy the time it takes to actually determine ownership of areas, the issue could have been sorted multiple times over. Unfortunately, this wider issue cannot be addressed without a Stormont minister in place.Cllr Andrews said he and Mr McGrath have raised the Mary Street problem with Newry, Mourne and Down Council, roads officials and the Housing Executive in a bid to determine ownership of the Mary Street paths and an adjacent alleyway.He added: ldquoWe have undertaken this course of action to ensure that the adequate response is made and the area cleaned up as soon as possible..prettyPhoto

title: Comber man taking on 28k mountain trail to raise funds for local charities
story: A COMBER man has challenged himself to run a tough k mountain trail to raise cash for charities, including Cancer Focus Northern Ireland.Daniel Heaney is getting fitter by the day and is raring to hit the Wicklow Trail Run in September.Daniel works for Troup Bywaters and Anders, which is pledging to raise pound, for local charities to mark their th year in Belfast.Cancer Focus NI also celebrates a big birthday ndash the charity has been helping local cancer patients and their families in Northern Ireland for the past  years.For Daniel, running is a way to be a part of the challenge and do his bit to help his company reach their target.ldquoIn the last year I have completed  runs, running just over  kilometres. However, I wanted to challenge myself and this will be a great stepping stone into longer distance running for me, he said.ldquoThe trail is k, with over , metres of climbing, presenting a completely dferent challenge for me mdash but Irsquom really enjoying getting out training and seeing the natural beauty of the world.ldquoI really wanted to support the Troup Bywaters and Anders challenge and Cancer Focus NI does such great work in the community.Louise Richardson, Corporate Fundraising Officer for Cancer Focus NI, said: ldquoWe are so grateful that Daniel has signed up to the Wicklow Trail Run to raise money for Cancer Focus NI.ldquoItrsquos not an easy challenge with the long distances and steep inclines but it is a great way to raise money for such a worthwhile cause.Cancer now affects one in two people and over , cancer diagnoses are made in Northern Ireland every year.Louise added: ldquoAll Cancer Focus NI services are provided free of charge for cancer patients and their families but we do need public support to help raise the necessary funds to continue our valuable work.ldquoSo, we would like to say a huge thank you to Daniel and his supporters. The money they raise will make a real dference.If you have any concerns about cancer call Cancer Focus NIrsquos free NurseLine on   .To find out more about Cancer Focus NI events, please call Kathryn Holland on   , email kathrynholland@cancerfocusni.org or visit www.cancerfocusni.org..prettyPhoto

title: Cruel exit for Down heroes
story: DEVASTATED, bruised and battered, Down camogs were totally crestfallen as they dejectedly trooped of St Tiarnachrsquos Park, Clones, on Saturday, knowing this was a game they should have won.Despite not being at their best, Down still had the majority of play, but were naively caught out several times on the break and also registered  wides over the hour as Westmeath rode their luck to secure a place in the All-Ireland decider against Galway.This was an exhilarating, bur gruelling contest from start to finish.Down started in a hurry and Fionnuala Carr gave them an early lead when she blocked an attempted clearance and split the posts with great composure.With three minutes gone and against the run of play, Westmeath broke from defence and used the pace of Michelle Murtagh to run into space before firing over the equaliser.Two Niamh Mallon frees then gave Down a deserved - to - lead, but they had worryingly notched up five wides inside the first  minutes.Westmeath slowly settled to the job on hand and with  minutes gone Pamela Greville converted a rsquo before Megan Dowdall raced away from her marker to give the Lake County an unexpected - to - lead after  minutes.Down were unfazed by this setback and Mallon swooped in the th minute to leave a point in it. The remaining minutes of the half were played at a hectic pace with some tremendous play on show.Sheila McGrath and Greville handed Westmeath a three-point lead before Mallon and Dowdall swapped points as the game entered added time.However, Down had the bit between their teeth and three inspirational scores from Finnuala Carr, Aoe Keown and Mallon brought the sides level at - to - with time practically up.Westmeath were not to be denied a first half lead and a converted Greville free sent her side in at the break with a hard-earned - to - lead.The second half was every bit as competitive with Down again dominating the share of possession, but they continued to struggle to put that advantage to good use.Frees from Greville and Mairead McCormick and a magical strike from McGrath suddenly had Westmeath - to - ahead after  minutes.Down went for broke and minutes after Mallon and McCormick exchanged points, the predatory Saoirse Sands struck with venom when she netted after taking control of a Fionnuala Carr free.Paula Gribben reduced the deficit to two points before Greville and Mallon again exchanged scores. Mallon was unerring in front of the posts and with four minutes remaining she left a point in it after scoring from play.Unfortunately, McCrossan took advantage of two more Down wides from frees when she gave her side a - to - lead with two minutes of added time played.Sara Louise Carr kept the pot boiling with a th point for Down, but this was the last score of the game as the referee blew the final whistle on the resumption of play.Down: M McNally, N Kelly, A Savage, C McGilligan, C Rocks, D Magee, K McMullan, A Keown , P Gribben , S L Carr , D Savage, S McCartan, N Mallon , C McGourty, F Carr . Subs: S Sandsfor C McGourty, A McAleenan for D Magee, K Tinnelly for C McGilligan, A McAleenan for A Keown .Westmeath: F Keating, A OrsquoMalley, M Scally, L Doherty, A Cully, F Leavy, Sandra McGrath, M Scully, N Horgan, M McCormack , S McGrath , M Dowdall , M Murtagh , P Greville , C McCrossan . Sub : A Doherty for N Horgan ..prettyPhoto

title: Dambusters fly again
story: THE eighth annual Extern Dambusters race took place in the Silent Valley on Saturday, attracting hundreds of runners to one of the most beautul race settings in the country.The race was organised by BornRun Events in association with their charity partners Extern.Runners had the option of a k as well as a half marathon course and k race and walk option. The half marathon was part of the Pure Running Championchip Ireland Half Marathon series.Weather conditions were perfect this year affording runners a clear view of the spectacular scenery that the Silent Valley has to offer.The half marathon route started outside the park on the Brackenagh West Road. Runners had already clocked up three miles when they reached the bright red gates welcoming them to the entrance to the Silent Valley.City of Lisburn ACrsquos Andrew Neill was first in a time of .., East Down ACrsquos Gordy Graham was second and Joshua McAteewas the third man home.In the womenrsquos race Gladys Ganiel of North Belfast Harriers was first lady over the line ..romping home five minutes ahead of fellow club mate Louise Smith. Catherine Roberts of North Down AC was the third female finisher over a tough course.The k race was won by Alexander McBridein . followed by Andrew Carrick QUB AC and third man across the line was William Annett .In the womenrsquos race it was Alice Clarkson of Cambridge Canoe Club who was the overall winner in . followed by Elaine Sprattin second place. Cecelia Mayeswas third over the line.The k winner was Paddy Hannan of Newry City Runners in a time of ., followed by Eamon McCann of Murlough AC finishing in second place and Lloyd Clarkecame third.In the womenrsquos race it was East Down ACrsquos Anna Gardiner who came first in an impressive . with Caitlyn Harvey of Lagan Valley AC and Lauren Madine of East Down AC hot on her heels for second and third place.Once again this year there was a special prize for the best represented running club at the race and the prize, for the second year running, went to local club Murlough AC.They picked up  free race entries for the upcoming Minnowburn race part of the award winning BelfastRun Forest Run race series.Runners enjoyed refreshments in the form of a post-race BBQ sponsored by LIDL-NI and Hovis. There was a great buzz as the runners tucked into their hot dogs and exchanged stories of their race experience.BornRun Events would like to thank sponsors Extern, NI Water, North West Community Ambulance , LIDL-NI, Hovis, and all those who helped out on the day.Their next race is at Minnowburn which is the first race in the award winning BelfastRUN FOREST RUN race series on Saturday, November . For details of this and all future events go to www.bornrunevents.prettyPhoto

title: Downpatrick sisters all ready for charity concert in memory of mum
story: DOWNPATRICK sisters Emma and Evie Telford are continuing their preparations for a fundraising concert in memory of their mum Lorna.The Quoile Bar and Bistro at the townrsquos Strangford Road is the venue for the September  concert mdash which is being sponsored by Phoenix Natural Gas ndash featuring the fabulous Belfast Community Gospel Choir.Emma and Evie are raising money for Cancer Focus NI with the forthcoming concert taking place just days after the fth anniversary of their mumrsquos passing following a long battle with lung cancer, despite being a non-smoker.But before the Belfast choir takes to the stage, Emma and Evie are encouraging people Province-wide to support the Cancer Focus Northern Ireland Forget Me Not Walk up Slieve Donard to raise funds for the charity.The walk takes place on Saturday, September  betweenam to pm, with all the money raised helping support local people affected by cancer.The September concert is the second that the sisters have organised in their mumrsquos memory. The first in  raised over pound, for a charity which helped Emma and Evie during their mumrsquos illness and after her death.To date, the sisters have organised several events in aid of Cancer Focus NI, raising thousands pounds for the organisation as their way of giving something back to the charity which provided key support to them at a particularly challenging time in their lives.The sisters are also planning to hold a raffle on the night of the September concert with all proceeds going directly to a charity which has worked with many families across the district.Emma and Evie want to help the charity which provides vital support to children who have a parent suffering from cancer and those who have lost a mum or dad to the disease.ldquoEvie and I are delighted to organise another concert in memory of our mum whom we miss very much, said Emma.ldquoWe also hope people will take on the challenge of the Forget Me Not Walk next month and take in the spectacular views from the Mournes as they remember someone special who is no longer in their lives.Emma and Evie are proud to keep their mumrsquos memory alive by fundraising for Cancer Focus which supports children who have experienced a loss similar to them.ldquoThe charity provides a wide range of services for cancer patients and their families. Evie and I are keen to give something back for the help and support we have received from the Cancer Focus Family Service and its wonderful staff, said Emma.ldquoWe are proud to be associated with the charity and know that mum would be delighted that we are continuing to support Cancer Focus as it helped her during her illness.Evie said the forthcoming concert will be an event not to be missed and hopes people will support it to help us continue keeping their mumrsquos memory alive.Evie also hopes that people will support the Forget Me Not Walk, with her appeal echoed by Barbara Long, a Cancer Focus community fundraiser.ldquoWhen someone you love dies you may wish to celebrate their le and memory in a special way, said Barbara. ldquoYoursquoll know the best way to remember them but a Forget Me Not Fund offers a way that not only celebrates their le, but helps other local people affected by cancer.ldquoAll the money raised through the uniquely named fund will help support our vital services and fund cancer research in the local community. Each year in Northern Ireland , people are diagnosed with cancer, many of whom need support, practical help and advice.Barbara added: ldquoEvery penny we raise is spent in Northern Ireland and by setting up a Forget Me Not Fund, people could help change the lives of many today and for generations to come.Tickets priced pound. for the September  concert featuring the Belfast Community Gospel Choir which starts at .pm are available at Down Recorder reception or from Davidor Emma Telford . A limited number of childrenrsquos tickets priced pound are also available.Tickets and can also be purchased on line via the Cancer Focus website or contact charity representative Barbara Long, telephone , email barbaralong@cancerfocusni.org.The registration fee for the Slieve Donard event is pound, with the charity suggesting each walker raises pound.To sign up or to find out more about the Forget Me Not Fund, email barbaralong@cancerfocusni.org, telephone    or visit cancerfocusni.org forgetmenotwalk..prettyPhoto

title: From the pages of the Down Recorder%2C August 21%2C 1979
story: MINERSTOWN mdash A canoeist helped save the lives of three brothers when he sparked off a dramatic air and sea search in Dundrum Bay on Sunday.The brothers had been out fishing in a nine-foot dinghy when they were dragged out to sea in strong currents, but they were successfully rescued thanks to the alertness of the canoeist, who raised the alarm.Newcastle leboat was launched and a Scout helicopter from Ballykinlar army base was sent to the scene. Within hours, the three Belfast brothers were back in Newcastle harbour where anxious relatives awaited news of their ordeal.Philip Sharp and his brothers Johnand Markhad left Minerstown Park Caravan Site wearing only trousers, pullovers and with only two lejackets between them. They started to fish about  yards offshore, but it was when they decided tohome that they hit trouble.They struggled to make any headway against the strong outgoing tide. ldquoWe just drted further and further away until the shore was just a haze, Philip said.They did not realise, as they drted six miles out to sea, that the alarm had been raised and the Newcastle leboat was on its way to their rescue, along with the helicopter..ldquoThe helicopter circled over us until the leboat came, Philip continued. ldquoThey took us on board and gave us hot soup and a tot of rum.ldquoI donrsquot think we have ever been so glad to see anyone in our lives. Altogether we were six hours at sea.The incident earned the boys a sharp rebuke from a Coastguard spokesman, who said they had a lucky escape, and from Earl Roden, secretary of Newcastle leboat station, who has prepared a report for the RNLI.SAINTFIELD mdash Eighty workers at the McCleery and LrsquoAmie factory in Saintfield are to be laid off in October. News of the pay-offs came in a company statement which laid the blame on cheap imports.The managing director of the factory, Mr R A McKinnon, said production prices had rocketed while the price they received for their product had remained relatively unchanged.Last month more than  textile workers in Castlewellan were laid off. The provincersquos three Euro MPs are seeking an immediate freeze on the cheap American polyester imports which are endangering the man-made fibre industry in this province.NEWCASTLE mdash A terrorist bomb blitz, which could have knocked out Newcastlersquos entire bus fleet, was foiled last Thursday.Ulsterbus chief Werner Heubeck drove several buses away from danger after an eight-bomb incendiary attack at Newcastle bus station.Army bomb exports had rushed to the scene when a bus driver, about to begin his morning sht, had spotted an incendiary device.While they established that eight incendiaries had been planted on seven of the  buses parked in the depot, Mr Heubeck drove other buses to safety in another part of the yard.Mr Heubeck had travelled to Newcastle from Belfast and despite the advice of the security forces that he should not break the cordon around the station, he signed a waiver of responsibility and moved the buses.Newcastle police said that five of the devices had partially exploded, but caused little damage. Newcastlersquos bus fleet operated from the street until the all clear had been given.Back at his Belfast desk, Mr Heubeck said: ldquoAny risk I took was necessary. Everyone who lives here has to take risks. My drivers do, so I canrsquot opt out.SHRIGLEY mdash A new plastics factory in Shrigley opened this week and already has good off to a good start with several orders.The company, which will be known as Northern Ireland Plastics, has taken on ten workers and they aim to step up the number employed to  within the next two years.The managing director of the new firm, Mr Lance Walker, said that although the orders were not big, the company was nevertheless pleased and encouraged.The factory, which is sited at premises vacated by the tannery in Shrigley, will carry out processing and provide materials for the plastic packaging industry, such as fish boxes, meat packaging and seed trays.The opening was welcomed by local councillor Sam Osborne, who said the factory space had been lying idle for too long and he was pleased to see employment coming to the area.DOWNPATRICK mdash Plans are now at an advanced stage to provide St Patrickrsquos Parish in Downpatrick with a multi-purpose community hall and a major new youth club complex within the next two years.Most of the cost of the two facilities, believed to run into many hundreds of thousands of pounds, will be borne by the parish itself, which has planned a staggering spending budget.The sites for both schemes are within several hundred yards of St Patrickrsquos Church, which was renovated last year at a cost of pound,, and have been made possible by the response of local parishioners to recent fund-raising events.The go-ahead was given this week for demolition work to begin on the burnt-out remains of the former lsquoCanonrsquos Hallrsquo in John Street, which is to be used as the site for the new youth club.ARDGLASS mdash Work will start early next year on a new sewerage scheme for Ardglass, which will provide for the needs of the town and proposed new housing in the area.The scheme will begin in January and consist of the construction of new gravity sewers and pumping stations. These will intercept the existing outfall sewers and pump the contents to a new sewage works at Ardtole for treatment and discharge into the sea.The news has been welcomed by local councillor Dermot Curran, who said he was delighted that the work was to begin.KILLYLEAGH mdash Colin Martin, of Riverside, Frederick Street, Killyleagh, must feel hersquos the luckiest two year-old around mdash for he has just won a Down Recorder competition for a framed photo of motorbike rider Tom Herron.Colinrsquos postcard, which was sent in by his father, Derek, was the first correct entry out of the bag, and he duly received the photo, which has been autographed by the worldrsquos top riders, including Kenny Roberts and Barry Sheene.SAUL mdash The Saul Division of the Ancient Order of Hibernians made the trip of Carnlough last week for the annual AOH demonstration.After mass in the parish church the ision, led by St Patrickrsquos Accordion Band, parade through the area and Downpatrick en route for the Co Antrim venue.A recent cake and produce sale organised by the energetic committee raised pound, which will go towards the purchase of new unorms. The committee extend their thanks to all who helped in any way to make thea success.NEWTOWNARDS mdash Londonderry Park, Newtownards, is the venue on Saturday for the Co Down Grand Black Chapterrsquos demonstration when  preceptories from  districts will be in attendance.Including members of the bands, it is estimated that more than , will be on parade in the demonstration, making it the biggest in the province, and a further , spectators are expected to line the streets.SOCCER mdash Soccer stars of yesteryear were in abundance at the Downshire Hospital on Friday evening, but unfortunately few spectators were there to see them.The game was organised by Charlie Oakes, who encouraged a team of All-Stars to meet his own select side in a special challenge match, which was sponsored by Murphy Jewellers, Downpatrick. The match ball was provided by Magee Sports..prettyPhoto

title: Kathryn aims for gold at Gateshead
story: BALLYGOWAN swimmer Kathryn Glover is out to make waves this week at the World Transplant Games in Gateshead.Thirty-eight year-old Kathryn, a member of Ards Swimming Club, will compete in the m freestyle swim, m and m breaststroke and the m and m backstroke.She is extremely grateful for the support received from the Ards and North Down Sports Forum and Ards and North Down Brough Council in preparation for the games and was recently the recipient of a Gold Card.This entitles iniduals who are training for a specic event to complimentary use of leisure facilities within the Ards and North Down Borough Council area..prettyPhoto

title: Let’s Do charity extends reach to veterans in ROI
story: A CLOUGH-BASED charity offering active and challenging rehabilitation trips to service veterans in the UK is now extending its catchment to former members of the British armed forces in the Republic of Ireland.Letrsquos Do focuses on rehabilitation, challenge and comradeship for disabled veterans and has already held a pioneering safari to Botswana, as well as to motorcycle events across the UK and Isle of Man.Former Royal Irish Regiment soldier Rab Maxwell, founding member of Letrsquos Do, has seen membership grow steadily and is enthusiastic about future expansion, including development of a five acre Irish coarse fishing lake.With Lottery funding, as well as sponsorship and inidual donations, a number projects are in the pipeline.With charity status in UK and NI, Rab is keen to extend the reach to those veterans now living in the Republic of Ireland.As well as future safaris and trips there is a range of projects being considered such as training in dry stone walling, carpentry and basic constructions. Theyrsquove even plans in hand for a photography course taking a party to the Isle of Man.Now the board and trustees want to reach out to those veterans in the Republic of Ireland who could benefit from renewed comradeship and challenges.Rab, who is disabled following a motorcycle accident, says the possibilities are endless.ldquoEven just the simple fact of knowing that someone cares can make a huge dference, he said.Letrsquos Do can be found on Facebook and on the web..prettyPhoto

title: Local students selected to take part in Study USA programme
story: TWO local students are off to study in America.Leah Mudi and Leah Stoneman are among  students from across Northern Ireland on the British Councilrsquos prestigious Study USA programme.The programme enables students to study business or STEM subjects for a year in American colleges, across  States, helping to develop their career prospects when theyto Northern Ireland.Leah Mudi, who is from Ballynahinch, currently studies Food and Nutrition at Ulster University and will spend her year at Greensboro College, North Carolina.Leah Stoneman, who is from Saintfield and a Microbiology student at Queenrsquos University Belfast, is headed to Carroll University in Wisconsin.Jonathan Stewart, British Council Director for Northern Ireland, said: ldquoI am confident that the students departing for the US this year will be great ambassadors for Northern Ireland and will help to further important long-term links and connections between the two countries.ldquoThrough Study USA, students will have the opportunity to not only enhance their employability skills but also develop intercultural skills, which will help them to prepare to work in a global economy.ldquoWe wish them every success, and trust that new connections and friendships will be developed in the year ahead..prettyPhoto

title: Longer hours at leisure centre
story: SOUTH Down MP Chris HZZrd is calling for increased opening hours at Down Leisure Centre.Mr Hazzard has written to Newry, Mourne and Down Council to ask that they extend the opening hours to help meet the growing demand for local health and fitness facilities.The Sinn MP says he has been contacted by people complaining that they couldnrsquot access the new gym facilities.Mr Hazzard said the new leisure centre in Downpatrick has been a fantastic success, with increased membership and ldquorave reviews for the new facilities.ldquoHowever, a growing number of people feel that the opening times for the gym in particular are too restrictive and not only limits their ability to access the facilities on a regular basis, he said, remarking ghat there were also ldquounacceptable waiting times for cardio machines and other equipment.The gym is currently open from .am to pm three days per week, am to pm two days per week, am to .pm on Saturdays and from am to .pm on Sundays.ldquoSuch restrictive opening hours limit the ability of a large amount of people who want to use the facilities either early each morning or late at night, Mr Hazzard said. ldquoThis then puts huge pressure on the available equipment and classes during peak times.ldquoAs a result of modern work patterns and busy lestyles the vast majority of private gyms have either -hour access or early morning and late night opening times .ldquoI believe the new council facilities should be no dferent, offering everybody in our community the best possible chance to access modern health and fitness facilities at affordable prices..prettyPhoto

title: Montalto welcomes milestone customer
story: THE stunning Montalto estate in Ballynahinch has welcomed its ,th visitor mdash just under a year after its opening last September.The beautul visitor experience, designed to reconnect people with nature through the estatersquos magnicent surroundings, has achieved the major milestone as it prepares to celebrate its first birthday.Owned by the Wilson family, the estate features public access to manicured gardens, historic walks and trails, an exciting tree house and natural play area for children.There is also a welcome area featuring interpretation of the estatersquos history, a stylish  seat cafeacute and a unique retail space.As part of a continued investment strategy at the estate, future plans include the development of an events programme, further planting and the creation of more gardens.There are also plans to provide additional trails including a .km history trail highlighting areas of interest such as an early settlement site and the location of the famous Battle of Ballynahinch, which took place on the estate.Future plans also include further additions to the natural play area that has become a firm favourite with families.The estatersquos managing director, David Wilson, described the arrival of the th visitor as an ldquoincredible milestone in Montaltorsquos first year of business.He continued: ldquoWhat an amazing year it has been.ldquoWe have achieved our ambition of creating a high quality visitor attraction and have received excellent visitor feedback which, for us, is of the upmost importance. It has helped to reinforce decisions we have made as part of our continued commitment to delivering an excellent visitor product, service and experience.Mr Wilson said the estatersquos membership has been a huge success and been very well received, with repeat visitors enjoying its many benefits.ldquoWe would like to take this opportunity to thank our staff who have worked so hard to help us reach this milestone and everyone who has supported us in our first year, he continued.ldquoAs we plan for the future and the years ahead, we are very much looking forward to welcoming old and new visitors to Montalto.The estate of open from Wednesday to Sunday between am and pm with free access to the car park, welcome area, cafeacute and shop.Gardens, trails and walks are ticketed with prices starting from pound.and childrenpound.. Discounted rates are available for advance bookings online, while children under  are admitted free..prettyPhoto

title: Neale stunner is the ticket for YC
story: KILLYLEAGH left it late before booking their place in the second round of the Irish Cup on Saturday.It needed a stunning strike from Adam Neale in extra time to claim victory at the South Belfast venue on Saturday.The cup has been low on the YCrsquos priorities in recent seasons after the glory days that saw them make history by reaching the semi-finals in , but after this tricky win, Paul Sharvinrsquos side will hope to improve on their - elimination by Crumlin Star in last seasonrsquos competition.The old football analogy of a game of two halves could not be any more apt for this game - Killyleagh were dominant in the first half, with Rosario ruing a number of missed chances in the second half.JonJoe Sharvin, playing in an advanced position for Killyleagh with so many players still missing, had three great chances in the first  minutes. He fired one shot straight at the lsquokeeper, one went wide and a cross which narrowly evaded everyone in the box.Killyleagh did prove menacing and in the th minute nice link up play between Charlie Holland and Darren McConnell allowed him to release Jamie Sharvin, but he hot straight at lsquokeeper, Mark Hynes.Thomas Healy was next up for the Whites in the th minute. John Murray won possession on the half way line and drove through midfield, linking with Neale, who released Healy on a one-on-one with Hynes, but the stopper stayed upright to deny him.Rosario were happy to let the YC play in front of them and hit on the counter and their best chance in the first half fell to Conor Murray after some clever link up play with Michael Johnson. However, his driven shot ended safely in the arms of YC goalkeeper Aaron Carberry.The visitors then had their best chance of the half in the th minute. Neale did well to hold off a defender and release Healy on the edge of the box, but his shot was fired just over.Both teams changed formations in the second half and Rosario really started to create some great opportunities.The game sprang into le when Johnson was put through one-on-one with Carberry, but once again the lsquokeeper stood up and made a smart save, with Murray missing the rebound.In the th minute Rosario were awarded a penalty. A long ball over the top caught the Killyleagh defence out with John Murray conceding a penalty and then seeing red in the resulting melee.Up stepped Ciaran Gillan, who struck a sweet penalty only to see it saved superbly by Carberry.In the th minute Killyleagh reminded Rosario that they were still in the game as Niall Walsh nodded a corner back into the path of Dylan Kelly who just couldnrsquot make contact with the goal at his mercy.It proved not the Gillanrsquos day. In the th minute he had a great chance, but managed to smash it over and in the last minute his shot hit the crossbar.With  minutes of football unable to separate the two teams it went to extra time and it was going to take a special goal to break the deadlock. Step forward Adam Neale. Chasing a through ball from Jamie Sharvin, Neale fired the ball into the top corner leaving the lsquokeeper with no absolutely no chance to win the tie..prettyPhoto

title: Open day at charity centre in Newcastle
story: DAISY Lodge is hosting an open day at its Cancer Fund for Childrenrsquos therapeutic centre, in Newcastle next Tuesday.Daisy Lodge CEO Phil Alexander said the Cancer Fund for Children provided families with a therapeutic short break allowing them to spend much-needed time together, far removed from the pressures of cancer treatments.Phil will be hosting the open day and would be delighted to give tours of Daisy Lodge and Narnia Log Cabin.ldquoWith the introduction of midweek hospitality packages, when families are not staying at Daisy Lodge, local businesses are also very welcome to attend to see the full suite of facilities on offer, he said.ldquoWe are grateful for the support of the public and ask they continue to join with us to ensure we can be lsquotogether through cancerrsquo with young people and their families.ldquoOver the next year I want to connect with as many of you as possible and this open day, will be the first of a number scheduled throughout the year.Anyone wishing to attend the open day should contact Joan Burden at joan@cancerfundforchildren or telephone   ..prettyPhoto

title: Planners approve car park scheme
story: PLANNERS are recommending that a proposal for a new car park at the site of the former Down Council headquarters in Downpatrick should proceed, despite objections from residents.The approval recommendation is due to be discussed by members of Newry, Mourne and Down Councilrsquos Planning Committee at their meeting today.The site of the former local authorityrsquos base at the Strangford Road is currently being used as an unofficial parking area for bin lorries and other refuse vehicles. Earlier this year, a planning application was submitted to formally designate the area as a car park for council vehicles and staff cars as well.Concerned residents who live nearby and Downpatrick councillor Dermot Curran expressed opposition to the move, describing the unofficial parking area in front of the remains of the townrsquos former workhouse as an ldquoeyesore, highlighting the noise created by heavy refuse vehicles starting up in the morning.Council officials say they have sold part of the existing Strangford Road site to the Education Authority to pave the way for the development of Down Highrsquos new multi-million pound campus.They explained that part of the land which has been sold to provide a new main entrance to the school includes an area which is currently used for council staff parking.The local authority is seeking planning approval to develop remaining land at the front and side of the old workhouse to provide parking for staff and its fleet of vehicles.In papers submitted ahead of todayrsquos planning meeting, it is confirmed that  homeowners who live close to the Strangford Road site were informed about the car park proposal, with some expressing concern about the impact it will have on property values.Concern was also raised about vehicle engines starting as early as .am, particularly at weekends, with those opposed to the planning application insisting that commercial vehicles should not be parked close to residential properties.Outlining their reasons for recommending that the planning application should be approved, planners admit that the car park plan will impact on the remains of the former workhouse which is of special architectural and historic importance.However, they confirm that the Department of Communities Historic Environment Division accept the parking plan in principle, provided the scheme respects the character of the area, suggesting that ldquosoft landscaping between banks of spaces with a low wall constructed to the western boundary.ldquoThe site is well established as the former Down Council offices, with a refuse depot to the rear, the planning papers continue.ldquoThe area has been used for staff parking with this application to formalise the arrangement with staff parking to the front and small vans to be parked at the side. The works proposed will aim to upgrade the existing frontage and use hardstanding to provide a more formalised parking arrangement.Planners say the existing land is to be regraded and resurfaced with low walls and have confirmed that external lighting also forms part of the proposal, with the current entrance set to be widened and new gates installed. Hedge planting is also proposed to help screen some of the activities to the rear of the site.Signicantly, the planning papers spell out clearly that the new parking at the front of the site will be laid out for vans and staff vehicles, not refuse vehicles. Planners also insist the application does not represent a change of use to the site.The papers continue: ldquoThe application proposes to relocate staff parking to the site of the formerly demolished council administrative building and use the other side of the car park for some additional fleet vehicle parking, with designated parking spaces marked and circulation routes displayed through the site.ldquoThe proposal will not impact any more signicantly in terms of residential amenity as to what is already there at present.Planning Committee members will also be told today that as part of the sale of council land at the Strangford Road to the Education Authority that there will be a two-hour daily traffic restriction over the use of the existing main fleet access to the site for local authority vehicles.Council vehicles will not be permitted to use the entrance between .am and .am and between .pm and .pm, with planners explaining this clause was ed into the contract of sale with the Education Authority on the grounds of child safety to ensure students could not be injured by council vehicles.In addition, planners say it is anticipated that most council HGVs and bin lorries will be off site by .am, but that a few may not be, requiring the need for an access through the site to the Strangford Road. This access will also be used by vehicles whichto the site between .pm and .pm when the existing fleet entrance will be closed..prettyPhoto

title: Roads officials urged to review traffic light order in Downpatrick
story: ROADS officials have been asked to conduct a major review of traffic light sequencing in Downpatrick town centre.The call comes in the wake of increasing concern about problems in a number of areas which is leaving residents and pedestrians frustrated.The call for the review of the traffic lights timing has been issued by South Down MLA Colin McGrath who revealed that he has received what he described as ldquomultiple reports from people on the issue.The MLA said some have raised concern about the lights operating out of sequence, explaining that this can be ldquoincredibly frustrating for pedestrians and road users.Confirming that he has raised the issue with roads officials, Mr McGrath said he wants the exercise to focus on where problems have arisen.ldquoIt is unfortunate to see this particular element of our roads network fall short of the standard which we have come to expect, said Mr McGrath. ldquoIt is essential that when the review is carried out that any necessary works are completed as soon as possible.ldquoThere is a great deal of frustration in the Downpatrick area due to the delay in completing the necessary regeneration works at Irish Street, a project which has still not reached its conclusion.Mr McGrath argued that this level of frustration ldquocompounds and unfortunately results in drivers and pedestrians taking chances at crossings and lights.He added: ldquoUnless the ious statutory bodies are willing to work together to ensure these issues are dealt with, then we are only going to rumble from issue to issue without seeing adequate road provision provided for the thriving community hub that is Downpatrick.ldquoThe people in the community want these issues addressed and have made that very clear to me..prettyPhoto

title: Ruth Maguire’s family raise £9%2C000 for Newcastle RNLI
story: THE family of Newcastle woman Ruth Maguire, who drowned in Carlingford Lough in March, have raised pound, for Newcastle RNLI in her memory.Newcastle RNLI was involved in the search for the mother of four along with other search and rescue agencies and recovered her from the lough after an extensive search.Staff at the leboat station were incredibly moved by the kind gesture from the  year-oldrsquos loved ones and have expressed their deep gratitude for the substantial donation.Following the tragedy, Ruthrsquos family carried out numerous fundraising events between Newcastle and Belfast. These included a sponsored walk of Slieve Donard and her brother-in-law completing the Belfast Marathon.A major fundraising night was also held in Byransford GAA club in Newcastle which was supported by people throughout the county.The cheque was recently handed over to Newcastle RNLI by members of the Maguire family, which included Ruthrsquos fianceacute, Jim Grfin, who she was due to be married to last week.Newcastle Leboat operations manager Lisa Ramsden said the crew were ldquocompletely overwhelmed by this donation.She continued: ldquoIt was our sad duty to help bring Ruth home that day but the crew were honoured to be able toher to her loved ones.ldquoRuth was a local girl and we felt her loss. It was a dficult callout for the station and our hearts went out to her family and friends.ldquoWe are astounded that in the weeks and months following her loss, that the family thought of others at this time and raised funds in her memory. Itrsquos a beautul and fitting tribute to Ruth and we are extremely grateful for it.Ms Ramsden added: ldquoWe will always remember Ruth and are proud that the funds raised in her memory will be spent here in Newcastle to help the work of the RNLI in saving lives..prettyPhoto

title: Screening of short film on Canon’s Excursion
story: DOWNPATRICKrsquoS Ballymote Centre is the venue this Friday evening for the screening of a special short film on the old Canonrsquos Excursion.Every summer, over  buses packed with local families would head off from Downpatrick for a day in Newcastle which to some excited children at the time seemed like a million miles away when in reality it was literally only up the road.New shoes and clothes were purchased ahead of the annual excursion so everyone was looking their best, with families gathering at the St Dillonrsquos Avenue sports pitches before marching to the townrsquos bus station via Edward Street, John Street, Irish Street and Market Street.A fun-filled day was spent in Newcastle, when the summers always felt warmer than they are today, with families ing home by bus, exhausted after a frantic but thoroughly enjoyable day.The last excursion is believed to have been held in the s, but local people are being offered a unique opportunity to relive those halcyon days thanks to a new initiative being spearheaded by the Stream Street Residentsrsquo Association.It has helped put together a short film which captures some of the the sights and sounds of the Canonrsquos Excursion which was one of the key events in Downpatrickrsquos social calendar.The film will be screened this weekend with invitations extended to residents in Stream Street who are being encouraged to take their seats after pm. Following the screening, there will be tea, Paris buns mdash a staple of the annual excursion mdash and sandwiches served.John Gordon, who was involved with the work to commission the film, has praised the Housing Executive, Stream Street Residentsrsquo Association and others involved in bringing the project to fruition.His mum, Mary, has an old film from  which he has watched several times, explaining that it is fascinating to look back at some of the townrsquos old characters who feature in it. John also went on the Canonrsquos Excursion when he was younger.ldquoThe excursion really was a great day out and took place in an era where people did not have very much. Everyone looked forward to dressing up for the excursion and boarding a bus really was a big adventure, even though we were only going to Newcastle, he said. ldquoI hope Friday nightrsquos screening will bring back many happy memories for people.John said the project to produce a film depicting the Canonrsquos Excursion was launched around two years ago and hopes people will enjoy what they will see this Friday evening.ldquoOne person who features in the film is Basil McDowell, who many people will know. Basil was one of the excursionrsquos stewards and he will provide a short commentary about the annual event, added John..prettyPhoto

title: Sectarian graffiti at school blasted
story: RESIDENTS at a Downpatrick housing estate have reacted with fury after sectarian graffiti was daubed on a wall near their homes.The graffiti, which read lsquoSoldier F , IRA rsquo, appeared at the front entrance to Down High School at Mount Crescent last week, much to the anger and disgust of those who live nearby.They have condemned what happened and insist it was not done in their name, with residents adamant that young people from another part of the town were responsible.A spokesperson for the cross-community Mount Crescent and Bridge Street Residentsrsquo Association said they condemned what happened in the strongest possible terms and did not want to see any more graffiti in the area.In July, the residentsrsquo group organised a hugely successful fun day which was attended by local people and others from across the town. However, just hours before it was due to start someone painted lsquoIRA on the wall in front of the nearby Pilson Hall.The spokesperson revealed that when the graffiti appeared last week they contacted a specialist cleaner to have it removed and were prepared to meet the financial cost. However, the businessman agreed to do the work for free.ldquoNo one in Mount Crescent or Bridge Street wants sectarian graffiti. It does not reflect the good people who live at this part of the town, the spokesperson declared.ldquoWe were left disgusted at what happened given that we are working hard to promote our area and secure new investment, just like many other community groups across Downpatrick. This despicable act was not done in our name and we condemn those responsible.ldquoWe are not prepared to let those responsible have a negative impact on the good people, from all religions and races, who live at this part of Downpatrick. This must not happen again.The spokesperson said the residentsrsquo group is a key member of the Downpatrick Community Collective, an umbrella organisation for community groups across the town.ldquoWe all get on well together and take part in joint projects. We trust that our community collective colleagues will recognise that the sentiments expressed in the recent graffiti is not what we are about.ldquoWe work with people from across the town and liaise closely with them on a regular basis. We are vey much a mixed community and indeed are proud of this fact. The graffiti daubed on the wall of Down High School in no way reflects the people of this area.The spokesperson said residents were left ldquoshocked and upset by what was written and were in the process of taking steps to have it removed when a local businessman stepped forward to do it.ldquoWe have a fair idea who was responsible for the graffiti and hope that they will be apprehended. We cannot emphasis enough that what happened was not done on our name and we condemn those behind this. We will not let people tarnish the work that we are doing or the good name of the Mount Crescent and Bridge Street area.ldquoWe hope the fact that we took steps to contact a specialist cleaner when we were made aware of the graffiti speaks volumes about our views on this matter. Those responsible are clearly not aware of what we are about and the respect we have for all our neighbours across Downpatrick.The spokesperson added: ldquoWe will not allow what happened to drive a wedge between us and others. If those responsible hoped the finger of blame would be pointed at us, they have failed. Like many others, we were left disgusted at what happened.Downpatrick councillor, John Trainor, said those responsible for the sectarian graffiti did not speak for the majority of local people, in particular, those who live in the Mount Crescent and Bridge Street area.Slamming the slogan as a ldquoshameful act, Cllr Trainor described Downpatrick as a ldquowelcoming place where respect is shown to all residents irregardless of creed, culture, religion or race. He said what happened last week does not reflect the town and its people and was in fact a hate crime.ldquoThose responsible do not speak for the majority of people here, declared Cllr Trainor. ldquoThere are many families who were impacted by the troubles, including some by collusion with the security forces, and this does not help to heal those wounds which are still very fresh.Cllr Trainor added: ldquoI condemn this act and all graffiti that is sectarian in nature which seeks to cause offence and hurt to a particular section of our community.Police investigating last weekrsquos incident have issued an appeal for information and want to hear from anyone who can assist them with their enquiries to come forward, using the non-emergency  number. Officers have also said they view what happened as a hate crime..prettyPhoto

title: Students celebrate exceptional results
story: STUDENTS and schools from across the district have celebrated another year of successful results in A Levels and AS examinations.There were increased numbers of students, driven mainly by another strong performance by girls, who gained the top grades of A* and A.Results were announced last Thursday and while students can get their results online, many still come to their school to celebrate with teachers and friends.For AS students mdash where the exam represents half of their final A Level grademdash the results give an indication of what they might expect to achieve next year.Justin Edwards, Chief Executive of the Council for the Curriculum, Examinations and Assessment , congratulated all students and said: ldquoNorthern Ireland students continue to perform well, with increases across all grades. There was a slight increase in those receiving the A* Grade this year.ldquoMathematics remains the most popular A level, with  in  students studying the subject. The proportion of students taking STEM subjects and Languages has decreased slightly, however STEM subjects continue to account for over one-third of A level entries in NI.All four Downpatrick schools offering A Levels said that their students had performed well.Down High School said that % of its students achieved grade C or higher this year.Principal Mrs Maud Perry paid tribute to the students and their achievements. ldquoThese results are a delightful way for our students to finish their seven years of post-primary education in Down High ndash or their two years for the large number who joined us in our inclusive sixth form, she said.ldquoTwenty-one Year  students secured at least three A or A* grades across the large range of subjects offered to post- students by the school. Over one third of the year group secured two A grades or better at A-level. There were  A* or A grades achieved, meaning that more than one in every  grades was an A or A*. Ninety-seven percent of all grades were C or better.Mrs Perry said that she was particularly pleased by the results achieved by the many pupils who joined the school in Sixth Form.She also acknowledged the excellent collaboration between Down High and the South Eastern Regional College, which deliveredBTEC Level  Subsidiary Diplomas in ICT, Engineering, and Sport.ldquoWe are delighted by the fact that % of the BTEC grades achieved were Distinction* or Distinction, which have A* and A equivalence, she said.Pupils in Year  also received their grades last week and twenty-six students achieved three or four A grades in their first year of study, with  A grades being attained ndash one third of all grades awarded.St Patrickrsquos Grammar School, which is facing a merger with De La Salle High School and St Maryrsquos High School next year, reported that % of its students achieved grades at A* to C.Principal Mr Joe McCann said: ldquoOur students are not only celebrating their results today but they are also celebrating gaining entry to their chosen university places many of our students have secured third level places in Queenrsquos University Belfast and University of Ulster while others will be travelling to universities in the South of Ireland, Scotland and England.Mr McCann also acknowledged the tremendous work done by both students and staff in preparation for the exams and the wonderful successes encountered along the way through extra-curricular and enrichment opportunities.Wishing the Class of  luck in their chosen pathways, Mr McCann added: ldquoThey are an exceptional group and I am confident that many exciting opportunities lie ahead. Their parents should be very proud of the well-rounded young adults they have become.The principal of De La Salle High School said that his students continued to break all records this year.Mr Ciaran Maguire said that % of students at the boysrsquo school achieved three A Levels at A*- E with % of students having achieved  A Levelrsquos A*-C .ldquoExpectations were always high for these students and over the past two years they have worked extremely hard with their teachers, said Mr Maguire. ldquoDecision time now for these boys as to where next, but with results like these lsquothe world is their oysterrsquo.Mr Maguire spoke of the ldquoproud tradition of students from St Columbarsquos College in Portaferry moving to the school and mentioned Emmett Edge who has achieved three A levels at A*-C .Single sex school St Maryrsquos High reported that % of students passed their AS and A Levels.Principal Ms Rosemary McLaughlin congratulated her students. ldquoThe success of students in this school is a reflection of their hard work, effort and enthusiasm that they have shown throughout their time in St Maryrsquos High School, plusthe dedicated teaching and non-teaching teams that have gone the extra mile in supporting the students, she said.Assumption Grammar School in Ballynahinch reported that % of its students passed at least two A Levels with almost % of all grades at A*-C.Principal Mr Peter Dobbin said: ldquoThere were many success stories at an inidual level, with students gaining entry to a range of courses at many of the UK and Irelandrsquos top universities. Notably, Anna White was the top Assumption achiever with a remarkable four A* A grades at A level.ldquoAcademically, our students have surpassed even our highest expectations. Todayrsquos results are proof that our commitment to ensuring every student reaches their full potential remains at the forefront of the Assumption experience.The principal of St Colmanrsquos High School and Sixth Form College in Ballynahinch, Mr Mark Morgan, reported that % of its students achieved three A*-C grades this year.He said: ldquoWe are delighted with the % A-Level achievement and congratulate students and praised them for their determination, hard work and effort.ldquoAs an over-subscribed co-educational school that caters for pupils aged - in the heart of the Ballynahinch community, we look forward to welcoming back many students next week to enrol in Post- courses.ldquoWe wish a successful future to those students who will be completing courses at university and higher education college, including Queenrsquos University Belfast, Ulster University, Liverpool John Moorersquos University and Belfast politan College, as well as iniduals directly entering employment and Higher Learning Apprenticeships.St. Malachyrsquos High School in Castlewellan said that the current Year  students had ldquoachieved wonderful results yet again having surpassed all benchmarks and exceeding all targets set.Principal Mrs Orla OrsquoNeill reported that % of the A Level students were leaving with three good passes to go on to further study at top universities.ldquoThis is nothing less than we expected from a fabulous group of young people, she added. ldquoAs an all ability school we are extremely proud of their achievements ndash they are up there with the best, yet again.. We celebrate the potential in everyone, we put our words into action and we provide our students with the opportunities todevelop their inidual goals and aspirations.Students of Shimna Integrated College in Newcastle also celebrated their A level results last week as they prepare to head off to Manchester, Dublin, Belfast, Liverpool among other university and college destinations.Principal Kevin Lambe said: ldquoNormally we make a particular point of celebrating all our results equally, but this year pride of place must go to Gabriel Corrigan, who achieved four A*s in maths, further maths, physics and chemistry mdash outstanding results.ldquoOf course, success at A Level for all our students is aof achieving the grades they need to move on to the course and the college where they want to be, and we are delighted that the vast majority of our students are placed very happily at universities and colleges across the country..prettyPhoto

title: SureStart open day successful
story: DOWN Sure Start team organised an open day for local families at its headquarters in Downpatrick on Monday.The event provided an opportunity for everyone to meet staff, view the building and gain information on the wide range of services and programmes offered.Down Sure Start, whose main site is at Mount Crescent, with a sister site at Railway Street, Newcastle, works in collaboration with local statutory, voluntary and community organisations to provide services and give children the best possible start in le.A spokesperson for the team said: ldquoAll services provided in the catchment area are free of charge to expecting families and families with children under four years- ld.ldquoSome of these services include health visiting and midwery support, breastfeeding support, both ante natal and post natal support, healthy lestyle, parenting, early years and dads programme, home safety service, speech and language support, and programmes with families with additional needs, first aid programmes and family support services.If you would like to register with Down Sure Start contact the office on    or visit the website on: www.downsurestart. Alternatively,you are interested in volunteering with Down Sure Start contact   ..prettyPhoto

title: bomb explodes newtownbutler amid major security alert
story: Police at the scene of an ongoing security operation in Newtownbutler have confirmed that some form of explosive device has detonated in the area.Deputy Chief Constable Stephen Martin said: ldquoAt around .am this morning Police officers at the scene have reported an explosion in the area of the Cavan Road at its junction with the Wattlebridge Road. There are no reports of any injuries and officers are investigating the cause of the explosion.ldquoPolice had received a report that a suspect device had been left in the area of Wattle Bridge on Saturday evening. The area was secured by police and a full clearance operation began on Sunday morning.ldquoThe initial report received by police indicated that a device had been left on the Wattlebridge Road however the explosion occurred on the main A Cavan Road.ldquoWhile this investigation is at a very early stage I am of the firm belief this was a deliberate attempt to lure police and ATO colleagues into the area to murder them. Although this device was intended to kill police and army personnel the fact that it was placed on a main road the result could well have been devastating for anyone in the immediate vicinity.ldquoThis attack was indiscriminate and reckless and, whilst there is no doubt in my mind that police responding to this call were the target, the reality is that anyone could have been caught up in the explosion. We are extremely fortunate that the actions of officers who were first on scene meant that there was not serious injury or death.I wish to acknowledge and commend the bravery and commitment of those officers and army personnel at the scene of this attack.ldquoI would like to again thank the community for their patience and cooperation throughout the security operation as we seek to ensure their safety.The area around the scene will remain closed for some time while our officers conduct their investigations and ensure the area is safe.This website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: pre christmas dairy farming event at eikon centre
story: The Royal Ulster Winter Fair enters its fourth decade next week as the st Winter Fair in association with Danske Bank takes place at the Eikon Exhibition Centre, at Balmoral Park, near Lisburn.Farmers from across Northern Ireland will be travelling to the showgrounds at the Maze for the one-day event on Thursday next, December .Regarded as the premier event in the national dairy calendar, it provides an opportunity for farmers, exhibitors and industry specialists while in the showring, there will be keen competition as quality livestock from Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland compete for the coveted title of Supreme Champion.Danske Bank have sponsored the event since its inception in  and John Henning, Head of Agricultural Relations at Danske Bank commented: ldquoOur sole sponsorship of the Winter Fair now enters a fourth decade - quite an achievement in an era where such long term business relationships arenrsquot as common place, as they once were ndash and we are very proud to have sponsored one of the biggest events in the agri-food calendar in Northern Ireland during this time.We value our close links with the Winter Fair and hope that our investment in the event - both financial and people - has contributed to the undoubted success of this major dairy showcase.ldquoOur support for the Winter Fair reflects a strong and ongoing commitment to the wider agri-food industry in Northern Ireland ndash both in terms of signicant lending to the sector and expertise of our dedicated Agribusiness team.ldquoItrsquos the event lsquowhere the dairy industry meetsrsquo each December and I have no doubt that this yearrsquos Winter Fair on December  will be another outstanding success - despite dficult times in the industry and ongoing uncertainty for dairy farmers.On the cusp of Christmas, visitors flock to the Winter Fair and observe the highest quality of livestock competing. This year the RUAS are delighted to welcome Paul Trapp, who is travelling from Wisconsin, USA, to judge. The event is also a great chance to interact with  dairy related trade exhibitors on the most relevant technological advances, dficulties and solutions in the industry. Rhonda Geary, Operations Director, RUAS said: ldquo saw the move of Winter Fair to our new purpose built exhibition venue, Eikon Exhibition Centre at Balmoral Park. The move has worked brilliantly and attracted one of the largest attendances to date. In preparation for the st Winter Fair we have increased the livestock accommodation and now have stalling, washing and milking facilities for  cattle. There is m of exhibition space and a full house of  trade stands. During the Winter Fair there is a busy Seminar Suite with talks presented every half hour from am until .pm.Dr. John Bailey from AFBI will speak about better phosphorous management, Bobby Irwin of United Feeds presents a paper on getting the lactation to the right start and Roberta Simmons of the YFCU and Barclay Bell, President of the UFU will speak about succession on farms.CAFRErsquos Martin Mulholland will be advising on feed efficiency this winter, making optimum use of grass silage while Christopher Osborne form the UFU will speak about dairy commodity markets and the prospects for .Dr. Sam Strain and Sharon Verner from the Animal Health and Welfare Northern Ireland will look at improved biosecurity and BVD while Jessica Sloss from Red Tractor, speaks about the farm assurance scheme.The live calf rearing demonstration will be making afor the  Show. Gorteade Cow Care owned by Barry OrsquoLoughlin will be displaying a fully ing calf igloo with veranda and Heatwave ad lib calf feeder.One of the innovative technological features at next weekrsquos Winter Fair will be the Northern Ireland launch of the CalfApp and Calf Cloud by Volac which won gold at Eurotier in Hannover. It gives information about changes in drinking pattern and fluid intakes and monitors calf health.The launch of the Winter Fair was held at Draynes Farm, near Lisburn, where Michael Drayne led a tour of agricultural journalists and industry representatives around his farm and milk bottling plant. The milk botting plant began when his father began with a horse and cart. Now the business has a fleet of vans distributing milk and dairy produces to customers in four counties. However their products are supplied to customers across Ireland through the Henderson Food Service and other companies.The borehole gives Draynes Farm a constant supply of water which is also useful to soften the mains water for washing.A KVA solar  plant has been installed on the roofs of some of the buildings.Draynes Farm processes m litres of milk per year and operates Monday to Friday with their own supply of . million litres of farm milk held over the weekend until the beginning of a new week. A total of  staff are employed in all departments.The Draynes Farm dairy herd uses three Lely Astronaut A milking robots. The cows visit the robots on average . times per day averaging  litres per day with some exceeding litres. If this is the first time you have subscribed to emails from JPIMedia Ltd, the publishers of Belfast News Letter, please check your inbox to very your email address.  .html.valAt our Belfast Window on Wildle reserve we recently hosted another great bat walk event, writes Brian Campbell - RSPB NI.So, while we at the RSPB are mostly known for our work with birds, we often host bat walks too and are helped out on many occasions by our friends in the NI Bat Group.It’s easy to see why people are fascinated by bats. Their unique wing structure along with their light weight enables them to go to places that other land-based mammals would find unmanageable. Their limbs are highly modied for flight, so they find it dficult to move around on the ground. When they are not flying, they rest hanging upside down from a tree branch using their sharp claws.Roosting in caves, trees or draught-free buildings each species has their own preferred roost, usually near its main food source. They eat insects including moths and midges, so are considered a very important natural pest controller. Echolocation aids their navigation when hunting for prey on the wing at night. Bats are creatures of habit, ing to their favourite roost each year..ev-modals .modal.in .modal-dialog .photo-article-notier-default .ev-widget .photo-article-notier-default .photo-article-notier-default .ev-widget p @media.photo-article-notier-default .ev-widget p #jp .main-content .ev-widget#sticky-footer .sticky-footer-banner .photo-article-sticky-footer-banner .photo-article-sticky-footer-banner p @media@media#sticky-footer .desktop-sticky-footer_text,#sticky-footer .desktop-sticky-footer_button #sticky-footer .fluid-container #sticky-footer .mobile-sticky-footer_button Northern Ireland has eight species of bats, all protected by European law. Apart from being incredible little animals to watch, bats are a valuable part of nature across the UK and can be a very welcome visitor to our gardens. Sadly, though, they’re becoming increasingly rare in the UK. Like so many other animals, a gradual loss of habitat and roost sites are making numbers decline at an alarming rate. As old trees are cut down, buildings disturbed and mines filled in, bats are left with very few natural roost sites. Making sure our gardens are thriving insect-rich feeding grounds for bats can help a lot. And, just as we do with nestboxes for birds, we can also provide alternative roost sites for bats in the form of bat boxes. You can find out more information on how to help bats via our website . So while our Belfast Bat Walk is done for another year, we have another fantastic event taking place in Enniskillen in September. What better date for a ‘Bat Detectives’ guided walk than Friday the th  It’s a great opportunity to learn more about bats, to see and hear them and immerse yourself in their world.
